elements.content: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a disorder affecting the elderly that is characterized by amyloid-β (Aβ) deposition in blood vessel walls of the brain. A series of 99mTc­(CO)3-labeled benzothiazole derivatives as potential SPECT imaging probes for cerebrovascular Aβ deposition is reported. Rhenium surrogate displayed high affinities to Aβ aggregates with K i values ranging from 106 to 42 nM, and they strongly stained Aβ deposits in transgenic mice (Tg) and Alzheimer’s disease (AD) patients. In vitro autoradiography on brain sections of Tg and AD patients confirmed that [99mTc]24 possessed sufficient affinity for Aβ plaques, and [99mTc]24 could only label Aβ deposition in blood vessels but not Aβ plaques in the parenchyma of the brain of AD patients. Moreover, [99mTc]24 possessed favorable initial uptake (1.21% ID/g) and fast blood washout (blood2 min/blood60 min = 23) in normal mice. These preliminary results suggest that [99mTc]24 may be used as an Aβ imaging probe for the detection of CAA.

elements.content: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a progressive degenerative disease characterized by Aβ deposition in the walls of leptomeningeal, cortical small- or middle-sized arteries, capillaries, and veins of the brain, and it always results in the rupture and dysfunction of cerebral vessels. The abnormal accumulation of Aβ protein leads to the formation of neuritic plaques in the brain, which is also one of the distinct pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). Neuropathological studies suggest that Aβ deposits in blood vessel walls and the brain parenchyma can proceed simultaneously or separately, resulting in obvious biological overlaps between CAA and AD. Although the relationship between these two diseases remains unclear, subtle differences exist between the vascular amyloid deposition in CAA and the parenchymal amyloid deposition in AD. For example, Aβ1–40 is more abundant in the cerebrovascular amyloid of CAA, whereas Aβ1–42 tends to be the primary form observed in the parenchymal plaques of AD. Based on the pathological detection, CAA is a fairly common clinical entity, present in approximately 10% to 40% of elderly individuals. More than 90% of AD patients have histological evidence that Aβ also deposits within cerebral vessels because these two diseases share a common pathogenesis. However, postmortal histopathological assessment is the only method to enable the definitive identification of CAA. In the clinic, elderly people with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) are always considered candidates for CAA diagnosis. However, the diagnostic reliance on cerebral hemorrhage as a surrogate marker for CAA has several limitations preventing the early detection of CAA. Therefore, the development of a noninvasive imaging method for accurate diagnosis and quantification of CAA would be highly significant.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) is a progressive degenerative disease characterized by Aβ deposition in the walls of leptomeningeal, cortical small- or middle-sized arteries, capillaries, and veins of the brain, and it always results in the rupture and dysfunction of cerebral vessels. The abnormal accumulation of Aβ protein leads to the formation of neuritic plaques in the brain, which is also one of the distinct pathological hallmarks of Alzheimer's disease (AD). Neuropathological studies suggest that Aβ deposits in blood vessel walls and the brain parenchyma can proceed simultaneously or separately, resulting in obvious biological overlaps between CAA and AD. Although the relationship between these two diseases remains unclear, subtle differences exist between the vascular amyloid deposition in CAA and the parenchymal amyloid deposition in AD. For example, Aβ1-40 is more abundant in the cerebrovascular amyloid of CAA, whereas Aβ1-42 tends to be the primary form observed in the parenchymal plaques of AD. Based on the pathological detection, CAA is a fairly common clinical entity, present in approximately 10% to 40% of elderly individuals. More than 90% of AD patients have histological evidence that Aβ also deposits within cerebral vessels because these two diseases share a common pathogenesis. However, postmortal histopathological assessment is the only method to enable the definitive identification of CAA. In the clinic, elderly people with spontaneous intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH) are always considered candidates for CAA diagnosis. However, the diagnostic reliance on cerebral hemorrhage as a surrogate marker for CAA has several limitations preventing the early detection of CAA. Therefore, the development of a noninvasive imaging method for accurate diagnosis and quantification of CAA would be highly significant.

elements.content: Aβ deposition, as a common pathological hallmark of both AD and CAA, is a target for imaging agents. Research on Aβ imaging agents for the diagnosis of AD in humans has achieved significant progress in past decades. [18F]­AV-45 (florbetapir/AMYVID), [18F]­GE067 (flutemetamol/VIZAMYL), and [18F]­BAY-94-9172 (florbetaben/NEURACEQ) have been approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration as clinical radiopharmaceuticals for the diagnosis of AD. [11C]­PIB, the most used Aβ imaging agent, has been reported for detection of CAA. However, [11C]­PIB could penetrate the BBB efficiently and was unable to distinguish Aβ deposits between within blood vessels and in cerebral parenchyma accurately. Similarly, other Aβ imaging agents designed for AD are unable to specifically diagnose and quantify CAA due to their limited selectivity for Aβ deposition in different regions. Thus far, limited research has been performed on the development of imaging agents for specific diagnosis of CAA. Kung et al. reported the “bivalent or trivalent ligands” containing two or three styrylpyridine binding cores as specific CAA imaging agents based on the reduction of brain uptake. According to this principle, reported herein is the design and biological evaluation of a series of negatively charged imaging probes with limited BBB penetration for the selective detection of vascular Aβ deposition. Benzothiazole scaffold as the binding moiety is connected to a 99mTc-chelating moiety via different length of carbon chains. The common chelation ligand iminodiacetic acid (IDA), which can form negatively charged compounds with the [99mTc­(CO)3(H2O)3]+ core, was easily introduced (Figure ).

elements.content: All reagents used in the synthesis were commercial products and were used without further purification unless otherwise indicated. The 99mTc-pertechnetate was eluted from a commercial 99Mo/99mTc generator which was obtained from Beijing Atomic High-Tech Co. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were obtained at 400 MHz on Bruker Avance III NMR spectrometers in CDCl3, DMSO-d 6 or CD3OD solutions at room temperature with TMS as an internal standard. Mass spectra were acquired using a SurveyorMSQ Plus (ESI) (Waltham, MA, USA) instrument. Reactions were monitored by TLC (silica gel 60 F254 aluminum sheets, Merck), and compounds were visualized by illumination with a short wavelength UV lamp (λ = 254 or 365 nm). Column chromatographic purification was performed on a silica gel (54–74 μm) from Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co., Ltd. X-ray crystallography data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II diffractometer (Bruker, Germany). Transgenic mice (C57BL6, APPswe/PSEN1, 12 or 23 months old, female) used as AD model and normal mice (C57BL6, 12 or 23 months old, female) were purchased from the Institute of Laboratory Animal Science, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences. Postmortem brain tissues from autopsy-confirmed cases of AD patients (64 years old, female, temporal lobe; 68 years old, female, frontal lobe), a CAA patient (70 years old, male, temporal lobe), and a control subject (79 years old, male, temporal lobe) were obtained from the Chinese Brain Bank Center. All protocols requiring the use of animals were approved by the animal care committee of Beijing Normal University.
elements.clean_text:
Materials and Methods

General Information

All reagents used in the synthesis were commercial products and were used without further purification unless otherwise indicated. The 99mTc-pertechnetate was eluted from a commercial 99Mo/99mTc generator which was obtained from Beijing Atomic High-Tech Co. The 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were obtained at 400 MHz on Bruker Avance III NMR spectrometers in CDCl3, DMSO-d 6 or CD3OD solutions at room temperature with TMS as an internal standard. Mass spectra were acquired using a SurveyorMSQ Plus (ESI) (Waltham, MA, USA) instrument. Reactions were monitored by TLC (silica gel 60 F254 aluminum sheets, Merck), and compounds were visualized by illumination with a short wavelength UV lamp (λ = 254 or 365 nm). Column chromatographic purification was performed on a silica gel (54-74 μm) from Qingdao Haiyang Chemical Co., Ltd. X-ray crystallography data were collected on a Bruker Smart APEX II diffractometer (Bruker, Germany). Transgenic mice (C57BL6, APPswe/PSEN1, 12 or 23 months old, female) used as AD model and normal mice (C57BL6, 12 or 23 months old, female) were purchased from the Institute of Laboratory Animal Science, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences. Postmortem brain tissues from autopsy-confirmed cases of AD patients (64 years old, female, temporal lobe; 68 years old, female, frontal lobe), a CAA patient (70 years old, male, temporal lobe), and a control subject (79 years old, male, temporal lobe) were obtained from the Chinese Brain Bank Center. All protocols requiring the use of animals were approved by the animal care committee of Beijing Normal University.

elements.content: A mixture of 2-(4-(methylamino)­phenyl)­benzo­[d]­thiazol-6-ol (256.9 mg, 1.0 mmol) and K2CO3 (429.9 mg, 3.1 mmol) in CH3CN (30 mL) was stirred at 90 °C. After 2 h, 1,3-dibromopropane (404.6 mg, 4.0 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was kept at 90 °C for an additional 2 h. Then, K2CO3 was filtered and CH3CN was removed under vacuum. The residue was suspended in petroleum, and the product was precipitated and filtered without further purification. Compounds 2–8 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR data are shown in the .
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Synthesis of Compounds 1-8 

A mixture of 2-(4-(methylamino)phenyl)benzo[d]thiazol-6-ol (256.9 mg, 1.0 mmol) and K2CO3 (429.9 mg, 3.1 mmol) in CH3CN (30 mL) was stirred at 90 °C. After 2 h, 1,3-dibromopropane (404.6 mg, 4.0 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was kept at 90 °C for an additional 2 h. Then, K2CO3 was filtered and CH3CN was removed under vacuum. The residue was suspended in petroleum, and the product was precipitated and filtered without further purification. Compounds 2-8 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR data are shown in the .

elements.content: A mixture of diethyl iminodiacetate (178.2 mg, 0.98 mmol), 1 (247.3 mg, 0.65 mmol), K2CO3 (268.7 mg, 1.95 mmol), and KI (107.7 mg, 0.65 mmol) in CH3CN (10 mL) was heated to reflux for 48 h at 90 °C. After CH3CN was removed, water was added, the resulting mixture was extracted by dichloromethane (3 × 20 mL), and the organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The organic solvent was removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (petroleum ether/AcOEt, 2/1) to yield 79.7 mg of 9 as a light yellow solid. Compounds 10–16 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR and MS data are shown in the .

elements.content: Compound 9 (79.7 mg, 0.16 mmol) was dissolved in MeOH (2 mL), and then 2 M NaOH solution was added (1 mL). The solution was refluxed for 2 h until compound 9 was completely hydrolyzed. Then, the pH value of the solution was adjusted to 8 by adding a few drops of hydrochloric acid (2 M), the mixture was refluxed for an additional 30 min, and then Re­(CO)5Cl (56.7 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added and the mixture was refluxed for another 2 h. After removal of the MeOH, water was added, and the resulting precipitate was washed with ethyl acetate to obtain 89.6 mg of 17 as a deep yellow solid. Compounds 18–24 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and HRMS data are shown in the .

Synthesis of Compounds 17-24

Then, the pH value of the solution was adjusted to 8 by adding a few drops of hydrochloric acid (2 M), the mixture was refluxed for an additional 30 min, and then Re(CO)5Cl (56.7 mg, 0.16 mmol) was added and the mixture was refluxed for another 2 h. After removal of the MeOH, water was added, and the resulting precipitate was washed with ethyl acetate to obtain 89.6 mg of 17 as a deep yellow solid. Compounds 18-24 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR, 13C NMR, and HRMS data are shown in the .

elements.content: Compound 24 could be recrystallized by the slow evaporation of a mixed n-hexane and CH2Cl2 solution to obtain X-ray quality crystals. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Bruker Smart APEXII CCD diffractometer at 100 K using graphite monochromated Mο Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL-97 program package.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Compound 24 could be recrystallized by the slow evaporation of a mixed n-hexane and CH2Cl2 solution to obtain X-ray quality crystals. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction measurements were performed on a Bruker Smart APEXII CCD diffractometer at 100 K using graphite monochromated Mο Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares on F 2 using the SHELXL-97 program package.

elements.content: To solutions of compounds 9–16 in EtOH (2 mL) was added 1 mL of NaOH solution (2 M). These mixtures were refluxed for 1 h until the hydrolysis was complete. Then, the pH value of these solutions was adjusted to 2 by adding a few drops of concentrated hydrochloric acid, and after filtration, the carboxylic compounds were obtained as yellow solids. A freshly prepared solution (1 mL) of the fac-[99mTc­(CO)3(H2O)3]+ intermediate (pH = 7) was added to a vial containing carboxylic precursors (0.5 mg) in EtOH (200 μL). The vial was sealed and heated for 20 min at 90 °C. After cooling to room temperature, the resulting mixture was purified by HPLC (Shimadzu SCL-20 AVP, SPD-20A UV detector, and Bioscan Flow Count 3200 NaI/PMT γ-radiation scintillation detector). Conditions for HPLC purification were as follows: Venusil MP C18 reverse phase column (Agela Technologies, 5 μm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm), CH3CN/H2O = 55/45 (0.1% of TFA) for [99mTc]17, [99mTc]18, [99mTc]19, [99mTc]21, and [99mTc]22; CH3CN/H2O = 50/50 (0.1% of TFA) for [99mTc]20, [99mTc]23, and [99mTc]24, 1 mL/min. Then, the collected fractions were neutralized by adding NaHCO3 powder. The identities of these 99mTc-labeled tracers were confirmed by coinjection and coelution with the corresponding rhenium complexes under the following conditions: Venusil MP C18 reverse phase column (Agela Technologies, 5 μm, 4.6 mm × 250 mm), CH3CN/H2O = 50/50 (0.1% of TFA) for all tracers.

elements.content:
The partition coefficients of 99mTc-labeled complexes were determined using a previously reported procedure.

Tissue Staining

Paraffin-embedded brain sections from mice and humans were pretreated according to previously reported methods. Brain sections were incubated with 10% EtOH solutions (1.0 μM) of 17–24 for 10 min at room temperature, and the adjacent sections were stained with thioflavin-S (0.125%). Finally, all sections were washed with 40% EtOH for 5 min. Triple staining was performed using complex 24 (1.0 μM in 10% EtOH solution), 2c (1.0 μM in 10% EtOH solution, a near-infrared fluorescence (NIRF) probe for Aβ), and FITC phalloidin (100 nM in PBS containing 1% BSA and 10% MeOH, a vascular smooth muscle cell (VSMC) marker) on the same fresh frozen brain section from Tg mice or wild-type mice. Fluorescent images were obtained using an Axio Observer Z1 (Zeiss, Germany) equipped with DAPI, GFP, and Texas Red filter sets.

elements.content: In vitro inhibition assay experiments were performed as described previously with some modifications. A mixture was prepared by combining 100 μL of Aβ aggregated fibrils (aggregated Aβ1–42 peptide, prepared as reported previously, 28 nM in the final assay mixture), 100 μL of radioligand ([125I]­IMPY, 100000 cpm/100 μL), 100 μL of inhibitors (complexes 17–24, 10–4 M to 10–9.5 M in EtOH), 100 μL of DMSO, and 600 μL of BSA (0.1%, pH = 7.4) with a final volume of 1.0 mL in borosilicate glass tubes (12 mm × 75 mm). Other steps were the same as described in the literature. For complex 24, an in vitro inhibition assay using Aβ1–40 aggregates was also performed using the same method. The binding and blocking assays were performed as previously described with some modifications. In these assays, 100 μL of Aβ1–40 aggregates or Aβ1–42 aggregates (7.27 μg/mL) was added to borosilicate glass tubes (12 mm × 75 mm) containing 100 μL of [99mTc]24 (3 × 106 cpm/100 μL) and 800 μL of 10% EtOH. The blocking assay was carried out in the same way as the binding assay, but in the presence of an excess of rhenium complexes 24 (0.5 μM) as blocking agents. The mixture was incubated for 2 h at room temperature and then filtered with an Mp-48T cell harvester (Brandel, Gaithersburg, MD) using Whatman GF/B filters. The bound [99mTc]24 on filters was detected using an automatic γ-counter (Wallac 1470 Wizard, USA).
elements.clean_text:
In Vitro Binding Inhibition Assays Using Aβ Aggregates

In vitro inhibition assay experiments were performed as described previously with some modifications. A mixture was prepared by combining 100 μL of Aβ aggregated fibrils (aggregated Aβ1-42 peptide, prepared as reported previously, 28 nM in the final assay mixture), 100 μL of radioligand ([125I]IMPY, 100000 cpm/100 μL), 100 μL of inhibitors (complexes 17-24, 10-4 M to 10-9.5 M in EtOH), 100 μL of DMSO, and 600 μL of BSA (0.1%, pH = 7.4) with a final volume of 1.0 mL in borosilicate glass tubes (12 mm × 75 mm). Other steps were the same as described in the literature. For complex 24, an in vitro inhibition assay using Aβ1-40 aggregates was also performed using the same method. The binding and blocking assays were performed as previously described with some modifications. In these assays, 100 μL of Aβ1-40 aggregates or Aβ1-42 aggregates (7.27 μg/mL) was added to borosilicate glass tubes (12 mm × 75 mm) containing 100 μL of [99mTc]24 (3 × 106 cpm/100 μL) and 800 μL of 10% EtOH. The blocking assay was carried out in the same way as the binding assay, but in the presence of an excess of rhenium complexes 24 (0.5 μM) as blocking agents. The mixture was incubated for 2 h at room temperature and then filtered with an Mp-48T cell harvester (Brandel, Gaithersburg, MD) using Whatman GF/B filters. The bound [99mTc]24 on filters was detected using an automatic γ-counter (Wallac 1470 Wizard, USA).

elements.content: For in vitro autoradiography studies, the pretreated brain sections of mice and human were incubated with [99mTc]24 (1.85 × 1010 Bq/L) or [125I]­IMPY (7.40 × 109 Bq/L) in 10% EtOH for 1 h at room temperature. The sections were then washed with 40% EtOH. After drying, the sections were exposed to a phosphorus plate (PerkinElmer, USA) for 60 min. The images were obtained using a phosphor imaging system (Cyclone, Packard). Finally, the same brain sections were stained by thioflavin-S. Ex vivo studies were carried out using Tg mice (23 months old) and age-matched case. A saline solution (10% EtOH) of [99mTc]24 (37 MBq) was injected into the tail vein. After 30 min, the mice were sacrificed by decapitation and the brains were removed and frozen at −30 °C. Then, sections with thicknesses of 20 μm were cut and exposed to a phosphorus plate for 10 h. The ex vivo autoradiograms were obtained as described above. Similarly, the same sections were stained using thioflavin-S to confirm the presence of Aβ deposits on blood vessel walls and in the brain parenchyma.

elements.content: A group of normal mice (ICR, 5 weeks, male, n = 5) were used for each time point (2, 10, 30, and 60 min) of the biodistribution studies. The mice were injected with 100 μL of saline solution (10% EtOH) containing 185 kBq of tracers via the lateral tail vein. The mice were sacrificed exactly at the above time points. The organs of interest were weighed, and the radioactivity was measured with a γ-counter. Finally, the percentage of the injected dose per gram (% ID/g) of blood or tissue was calculated (the results for some organs were expressed as % ID/organ).

elements.content: Rhenium complexes as surrogates of 99mTc complexes were successfully synthesized and fully characterized (Scheme ). 6-Hydroxybenzothiazole derivatives prepared as reported previously were reacted with dibromoalkane compounds using K2CO3 as a base in CH3CN to form a bromo-aliphatic intermediate with chemical yields ranging from 26.7% to 79.8%. Then, the bromo-aliphatic compounds 1–8 were conjugated with IDA chelating ligand in CH3CN with K2CO3 as the base and KI as the catalyst to generate precursors 9–16 with chemical yields ranging from 21.1% to 62.5%. The precursors were further hydrolyzed using NaOH as the base in methanol, and then the corresponding rhenium complexes 17–24 were achieved by reacting the hydrolyzed precursors with Re­(CO)5Cl under alkaline conditions (pH = 8). Complex 24 could be recrystallized by the slow evaporation of a mixed n-hexane and CH2Cl2 solution to obtain X-ray quality crystals. The ORTEP structure of 24 is displayed in Figure , and relevant crystallographic data are provided in Table S1 in the . The crystal exists in the form of a sodium salt with two crystal waters; specifically, one carbonyl oxygen atom of the IDA ligand is coordinated with a sodium atom, which is coordinated with two oxygen atoms from two water molecules. The coordination geometry about rhenium is a distorted octahedron consisting of the fac-[Re­(CO)3]+ moiety and a set of tridentate NOO ligands composed of a tertiary amine nitrogen and two carboxylated oxygen atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Synthesis and Radiolabeling

Rhenium complexes as surrogates of 99mTc complexes were successfully synthesized and fully characterized (Scheme ). 6-Hydroxybenzothiazole derivatives prepared as reported previously were reacted with dibromoalkane compounds using K2CO3 as a base in CH3CN to form a bromo-aliphatic intermediate with chemical yields ranging from 26.7% to 79.8%. Then, the bromo-aliphatic compounds 1-8 were conjugated with IDA chelating ligand in CH3CN with K2CO3 as the base and KI as the catalyst to generate precursors 9-16 with chemical yields ranging from 21.1% to 62.5%. The precursors were further hydrolyzed using NaOH as the base in methanol, and then the corresponding rhenium complexes 17-24 were achieved by reacting the hydrolyzed precursors with Re(CO)5Cl under alkaline conditions (pH = 8). Complex 24 could be recrystallized by the slow evaporation of a mixed n-hexane and CH2Cl2 solution to obtain X-ray quality crystals. The ORTEP structure of 24 is displayed in Figure , and relevant crystallographic data are provided in Table S1 in the . The crystal exists in the form of a sodium salt with two crystal waters; specifically, one carbonyl oxygen atom of the IDA ligand is coordinated with a sodium atom, which is coordinated with two oxygen atoms from two water molecules. The coordination geometry about rhenium is a distorted octahedron consisting of the fac-[Re(CO)3]+ moiety and a set of tridentate NOO ligands composed of a tertiary amine nitrogen and two carboxylated oxygen atoms.

elements.content: To prepare the 99mTc­(CO)3-labeled benzothiazole complexes [99mTc]17–24, the intermediate fac-[99mTc­(CO)3(H2O)3]+ was first obtained as described previously. Then, the hydrolysates of 9–16 were reacted with the intermediate to form crude 99mTc­(CO)3-labeled products by ligand exchange reactions (Scheme ). [99mTc]17–24 were obtained with high radiochemical yields (>90%) and high radiochemical purity (>95%) after purification. The radiotracers were identified by comparing the HPLC retention time with the corresponding rhenium complexes through coinjection and coelution (Table S2 and Figure S1 in the ). In addition, the log D values for [99mTc]17–24 (2.72 ± 0.15, 2.73 ± 0.11, 2.99 ± 0.31, 3.12 ± 0.36, 2.74 ± 0.23, 2.39 ± 0.05, 2.55 ± 0.11, and 3.03 ± 0.07, respectively) demonstrate that these tracers are suitable for brain imaging.

Tissue Staining

Staining of the brain section from Tg mice with complex 24 resulted in unambiguous and specific labeling of Aβ plaques in the cerebral parenchyma (Figure A) and blood vessels (Figure D); the results were in agreement with the thioflavin-S staining pattern of the adjacent section (Figure B) or costaining on the same sections using a NIRF probe 2c. Furthermore, intense labeling of Aβ deposits within the blood vessels and in the cerebral parenchyma with low background was also observed on brain sections of AD patient for complex 24 (Figure C,G). In contrast, no apparent labeling was observed in the brain section of normal mice and normal human (Figure S2 in the ). Similarly, good staining results were observed in the brain sections of Tg mice for complexes 17–23 as shown in Figure S3 in the . To explore whether 24-positive Aβ deposition influenced the structure of blood vessels, triple staining was performed using complex 24, 2c, and a VSMC marker FITC phalloidin on the fresh frozen brain sections from aged wild-type mice and Tg mice. As shown in Figure , VSMCs were arranged closely in parallel in wild-type mice, and the vessels did not stain with complex 24 and 2c. In contrast, complex 24 and 2c clearly labeled Aβ deposits in cerebral vessels of aged Tg mice, and VSMC arrangement was substantially disrupted in these vessels, which is a characteristic feature of CAA.

elements.content: Rhenium complexes 17–24 exhibited moderate affinities to Aβ1–42 aggregates with K i values ranging from 106 to 42 nM (Table and Figure S4B in the ). For complex 24, the affinity for Aβ1–40 aggregates is slightly stronger than for Aβ1–42 aggregates (IC50 = 37.0 ± 10.3 and 64.5 ± 7.8, respectively) (Figure S4A in the ). Furthermore, the direct binding potential of [99mTc]24 to Aβ1–40 and Aβ1–42 aggregates is shown in Figure ; the Aβ1–40 aggregate-bound radioactivity (%) was slightly higher than that of Aβ1–42 aggregates (10.15% vs 6.48%), while the intermediate [99mTc­(CO)3(H2O)3]+ displayed no remarkable binding to Aβ1–40 or Aβ1–42 aggregates. The binding of [99mTc]24 to both Aβ1–40 and Aβ1–42 aggregates could be blocked by over 80% (87.1% and 81.5%, respectively) by an excess of rhenium complex 24 (0.5 μM).

elements.content: To investigate the binding ability of [99mTc]24 to Aβ plaques at tracer dose, in vitro autoradiography studies were first carried out on brain sections of Tg mice and age-matched wild-type mice. As shown in Figure , [99mTc]24 exhibited excellent labeling of Aβ deposits within blood vessels and cerebral parenchyma in the cortical and cerebellar regions of Tg mouse brain, but this labeling was not observed in the wild-type case (Figure S5 in the ). The selective binding ability of [99mTc]24 was further examined using brain sections of AD patients. Interestingly, [99mTc]24 was found to strongly bind to CAA-laden cerebral arterioles, but not to parenchymal plaques in brain sections of AD human. In contrast, [125I]­IMPY, a common Aβ binding agent, labeled Aβ deposits in both cerebral arterioles and the parenchyma on congeneric brain section of AD human in in vitro autoradiography studies (Figure ). The similar in vitro autoradiography results were repeated on brain sections from different patients (Figures S6 and S7 in the ). To further confirm that [99mTc]24 has the potential to selectively recognize Aβ deposits located in cerebral arterioles, ex vivo autoradiography studies were performed in Tg mice and wild-type mice. As shown in Figure , autoradiographic imaging revealed the presence of many radioactive spots on the brain section of the Tg mouse but no remarkable radioactive spots on the normal mouse brain section, and the radioactive spots were found to concentrate at the site of the blood vessels in the Tg brain tissue as identified by in vitro fluorescence staining using thioflavin-S.
elements.clean_text:
Autoradiography Studies

To investigate the binding ability of [99mTc]24 to Aβ plaques at tracer dose, in vitro autoradiography studies were first carried out on brain sections of Tg mice and age-matched wild-type mice. As shown in Figure , [99mTc]24 exhibited excellent labeling of Aβ deposits within blood vessels and cerebral parenchyma in the cortical and cerebellar regions of Tg mouse brain, but this labeling was not observed in the wild-type case (Figure S5 in the ). The selective binding ability of [99mTc]24 was further examined using brain sections of AD patients. Interestingly, [99mTc]24 was found to strongly bind to CAA-laden cerebral arterioles, but not to parenchymal plaques in brain sections of AD human. In contrast, [125I]IMPY, a common Aβ binding agent, labeled Aβ deposits in both cerebral arterioles and the parenchyma on congeneric brain section of AD human in in vitro autoradiography studies (Figure ). The similar in vitro autoradiography results were repeated on brain sections from different patients (Figures S6 and S7 in the ). To further confirm that [99mTc]24 has the potential to selectively recognize Aβ deposits located in cerebral arterioles, ex vivo autoradiography studies were performed in Tg mice and wild-type mice. As shown in Figure , autoradiographic imaging revealed the presence of many radioactive spots on the brain section of the Tg mouse but no remarkable radioactive spots on the normal mouse brain section, and the radioactive spots were found to concentrate at the site of the blood vessels in the Tg brain tissue as identified by in vitro fluorescence staining using thioflavin-S.

elements.content: The time–radioactivity data on brain penetration and the distribution of [99mTc]24 in other organs are displayed in Table . The results show a relatively low brain uptake of 1.21 ± 0.22% ID/g at 2 min postinjection and rapid blood washout with an approximately 23-fold decline in blood radioactivity at 60 min postinjection. Other complexes, [99mTc]21, [99mTc]22, and [99mTc]23 showed lower brain uptake (0.80 ± 0.17, 0.61 ± 0.08, and 0.88 ± 0.14% ID/g, respectively, in Table S3 in the ). These tracers are similar to most imaging agents in that they are metabolized by the liver and intestine. [99mTc]24 also exhibits remarkable stability in vitro and in vivo. As shown in Figure S8 in the , [99mTc]24 exists in the blood almost completely in its parent form after 30 min postinjection, and more than 50% is present in the urine at that time.

These results suggest that [99mTc]24 may serve as promising candidate for SPECT imaging of CAA. The corresponding rhenium complex 24 with the longest carbon linker length (n = 6) displayed the highest affinity toward Aβ1–42 aggregates (K i = 42.2 nM) among the rhenium complexes with various lengths of carbon linkers (n = 3–6); this result verified that the steric hindrance imposed by the bulky metal chelator on the binding motifs is alleviated by carbon linkers of appropriate length, leading to an increase in the binding affinity to Aβ aggregates. Considering that the Aβ1–40 is more abundant in the cerebrovascular amyloid of CAA, the imaging agent for CAA should have higher affinity for Aβ1–40 aggregates. In the inhibition binding and direct binding assay, rhenium complex 24 and [99mTc]24 both displayed better affinity to Aβ1–40 than Aβ1–42 aggregates, which may allow selective detection of Aβ deposits associated with CAA.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

These results suggest that [99mTc]24 may serve as promising candidate for SPECT imaging of CAA. The corresponding rhenium complex 24 with the longest carbon linker length (n = 6) displayed the highest affinity toward Aβ1-42 aggregates (K i = 42.2 nM) among the rhenium complexes with various lengths of carbon linkers (n = 3-6); this result verified that the steric hindrance imposed by the bulky metal chelator on the binding motifs is alleviated by carbon linkers of appropriate length, leading to an increase in the binding affinity to Aβ aggregates. Considering that the Aβ1-40 is more abundant in the cerebrovascular amyloid of CAA, the imaging agent for CAA should have higher affinity for Aβ1-40 aggregates. In the inhibition binding and direct binding assay, rhenium complex 24 and [99mTc]24 both displayed better affinity to Aβ1-40 than Aβ1-42 aggregates, which may allow selective detection of Aβ deposits associated with CAA.

elements.content: The synthetic Aβ fibers used in in vitro binding assay do not correlate with the structure of Aβ deposits in Tg mice and human brain. Thus, in vitro assays using brain samples are considered more reliable. However, the autoradiography results with [99mTc]24 on human brains are different from the staining results of the corresponding rhenium complex 24, which stained Aβ deposits within both the blood vessels and the cerebral parenchyma. This difference could be explained by the fact that rhenium compound itself has different biological properties from the 99mTc-labeled complex, or it may result from the differences in concentration between [99mTc]24 and 24 applied in different experimental conditions. Previous reports showed that resorufin analogues could differentially detect Aβ deposits based on their localization in cerebral vessels versus the brain parenchyma at low concentrations, but these agents were nonselective at high concentrations. In the in vitro autoradiography experiment conducted here, the chemical concentration of tracer [99mTc]24 (nanomolar range) is significantly lower than that of rhenium complex 24 (micromolar range) used for the fluorescent staining experiment.

However, the autoradiography results with [99mTc]24 on human brains are different from the staining results of the corresponding rhenium complex 24, which stained Aβ deposits within both the blood vessels and the cerebral parenchyma. This difference could be explained by the fact that rhenium compound itself has different biological properties from the 99mTc-labeled complex, or it may result from the differences in concentration between [99mTc]24 and 24 applied in different experimental conditions. Previous reports showed that resorufin analogues could differentially detect Aβ deposits based on their localization in cerebral vessels versus the brain parenchyma at low concentrations, but these agents were nonselective at high concentrations. In the in vitro autoradiography experiment conducted here, the chemical concentration of tracer [99mTc]24 (nanomolar range) is significantly lower than that of rhenium complex 24 (micromolar range) used for the fluorescent staining experiment.

elements.content: Many 99mTc-labeled tracers with sufficient affinities displayed intense labeling of Aβ plaques in Tg mice but exhibited negative results in AD human brain samples; interestingly, [99mTc]24 not only displayed positive autoradiography results but also selectively detected Aβ within the blood vessels on brain section of AD human. However, it did not show such selectivity about the autoradiography results for the brain sections from Tg mice. First, it may be due to differences in the configuration/folding of Aβ plaques between human and mice. Second, the selectivity of [99mTc]24 to Aβ deposits in cerebral arterioles in brain sections from AD patient may result from differences in the degree of aggregation of the Aβ peptide. In the selected brain section from the AD patient, most of the plaques are diffuse, and the neuritic plaques with higher degrees of aggregation are barely visible, while the labeled plaques on the brain section of the aged Tg mice are mostly neuritic plaques. In contrast, the deposits in cerebral arterioles are denser than the diffuse plaques, so [99mTc]24 may only detect the deposits in cerebral arterioles due to their higher density. Another possibility is that [99mTc]24 preferentially detects aggregates of Aβ1–40, which is the major species of Aβ in CAA, while Aβ1–42 predominates in parenchymal plaques. Actually, [99mTc]24 displayed better affinity to Aβ1–40 than Aβ1–42 aggregates in in vitro binding and blocking assays. In addition, the result that [99mTc]24 specifically targeted only vascular amyloid deposition in human tissue is similar to the specific reactivity of a heavy chain antibody fragment (ni3A) for vascular Aβ on human brain section.

However, it did not show such selectivity about the autoradiography results for the brain sections from Tg mice. First, it may be due to differences in the configuration/folding of Aβ plaques between human and mice. Second, the selectivity of [99mTc]24 to Aβ deposits in cerebral arterioles in brain sections from AD patient may result from differences in the degree of aggregation of the Aβ peptide. In the selected brain section from the AD patient, most of the plaques are diffuse, and the neuritic plaques with higher degrees of aggregation are barely visible, while the labeled plaques on the brain section of the aged Tg mice are mostly neuritic plaques. In contrast, the deposits in cerebral arterioles are denser than the diffuse plaques, so [99mTc]24 may only detect the deposits in cerebral arterioles due to their higher density. Another possibility is that [99mTc]24 preferentially detects aggregates of Aβ1-40, which is the major species of Aβ in CAA, while Aβ1-42 predominates in parenchymal plaques. Actually, [99mTc]24 displayed better affinity to Aβ1-40 than Aβ1-42 aggregates in in vitro binding and blocking assays. In addition, the result that [99mTc]24 specifically targeted only vascular amyloid deposition in human tissue is similar to the specific reactivity of a heavy chain antibody fragment (ni3A) for vascular Aβ on human brain section.

elements.content: As very few reports have been published on imaging agents that specifically target CAA, the criteria for CAA imaging agents have not been fully established, especially in terms of the degree of BBB penetration. Bacskai et al. reported that vascular amyloid deposits in Tg mouse were weakly labeled after iv injection of thioflavin-T, while the amyloid deposits in the parenchyma were not labeled. Thioflavin-T is not expected to efficiently cross the intact BBB due to its positive charge and low lipophilicity. Likewise, Kung and co-workers have reported multidentate styrylpyridine derivatives that selectively detect CAA due to low brain uptake. Based on these results, decreasing the initial brain uptake may help to improve the selectivity of imaging agents to CAA. However, larger and hydrophilic molecule thioflavin-S failed to label either parenchymal Aβ deposition or vascular amyloid deposition when it was injected into a Tg mouse, and amyloid aggregates generally exist inside the blood vessels, especially in the early stage of CAA. Thus, imaging agents targeting amyloid aggregates in CAA should have a certain ability to penetrate the BBB; the moderate initial brain uptake of [99mTc]24 may be more promising. In this study, the control of brain uptake is only one aspect with the potential to enhance the selectivity, as [99mTc]24 itself is selective for vascular amyloid deposits according to the results from in vitro autoradiography studies on brain sections of AD patients. Moreover, the ex vivo autoradiography studies in Tg mice and wild-type further confirmed that [99mTc]24 has the potential to selectively recognize Aβ deposits located in cerebral arterioles.

elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

The results of our preliminary study suggest that a 99mTc(CO)3-labeled benzothiazole derivative, [99mTc]24, exhibited sufficient affinity for Aβ aggregates and could selectively label Aβ deposits in blood vessels of AD brain sections. The specific binding of [99mTc]24 and its selectivity to Aβ deposits in blood vessel walls were validated by ex vivo autoradiographic experiments with Tg mice. Further experimental data will be required to confirm the utility of [99mTc]24 as novel imaging agent for clinic research on CAA and identification of early or presymptomatic CAA.

cln_elements.content:
A mixture of 2-(4-(methylamino)­phenyl)­benzo­[d]­thiazol-6-ol (256.9 mg, 1.0 mmol) and K2CO3 (429.9 mg, 3.1 mmol) in CH3CN (30 mL) was stirred at 90 °C. After 2 h, 1,3-dibromopropane (404.6 mg, 4.0 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was kept at 90 °C for an additional 2 h. Then, K2CO3 was filtered and CH3CN was removed under vacuum. The residue was suspended in petroleum, and the product was precipitated and filtered without further purification. Compounds 2–8 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR data are shown in the .

Synthesis of Compounds <bold>9</bold>–<bold>16</bold>

A mixture of diethyl iminodiacetate (178.2 mg, 0.98 mmol), 1 (247.3 mg, 0.65 mmol), K2CO3 (268.7 mg, 1.95 mmol), and KI (107.7 mg, 0.65 mmol) in CH3CN (10 mL) was heated to reflux for 48 h at 90 °C. After CH3CN was removed, water was added, the resulting mixture was extracted by dichloromethane (3 × 20 mL), and the organic layer was dried over anhydrous MgSO4. The organic solvent was removed under vacuum, and the residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography (petroleum ether/AcOEt, 2/1) to yield 79.7 mg of 9 as a light yellow solid. Compounds 10–16 were obtained by the same method as described above. The yields and 1H NMR and MS data are shown in the .

cln_elements.content: The time–radioactivity data on brain penetration and the distribution of [99mTc]24 in other organs are displayed in Table . The results show a relatively low brain uptake of 1.21 ± 0.22% ID/g at 2 min postinjection and rapid blood washout with an approximately 23-fold decline in blood radioactivity at 60 min postinjection. Other complexes, [99mTc]21, [99mTc]22, and [99mTc]23 showed lower brain uptake (0.80 ± 0.17, 0.61 ± 0.08, and 0.88 ± 0.14% ID/g, respectively, in Table S3 in the ). These tracers are similar to most imaging agents in that they are metabolized by the liver and intestine. [99mTc]24 also exhibits remarkable stability in vitro and in vivo. As shown in Figure S8 in the , [99mTc]24 exists in the blood almost completely in its parent form after 30 min postinjection, and more than 50% is present in the urine at that time.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Biodistribution Studies

The time-radioactivity data on brain penetration and the distribution of [99mTc]24 in other organs are displayed in Table . The results show a relatively low brain uptake of 1.21 ± 0.22% ID/g at 2 min postinjection and rapid blood washout with an approximately 23-fold decline in blood radioactivity at 60 min postinjection. Other complexes, [99mTc]21, [99mTc]22, and [99mTc]23 showed lower brain uptake (0.80 ± 0.17, 0.61 ± 0.08, and 0.88 ± 0.14% ID/g, respectively, in Table S3 in the ). These tracers are similar to most imaging agents in that they are metabolized by the liver and intestine. [99mTc]24 also exhibits remarkable stability in vitro and in vivo. As shown in Figure S8 in the , [99mTc]24 exists in the blood almost completely in its parent form after 30 min postinjection, and more than 50% is present in the urine at that time.
